title: How to Make Marinated Goat Cheese

steps.headline: Rinse the fresh herbs and put them in a jar.
steps.description:
Rinse small bunches of fresh herbs under cool water or use a mixture of your favorite fresh herbs. Put half of the herbs into an 8-cup (1.81 kg) mason jar. If you don't have that, you can use a large bowl that's at least three inches (7.5 cm) deep. You'll need:
1 small bunch fresh rosemary
1 small bunch fresh thyme
1 small bunch fresh oregano
1 small bunch fresh basil
1 small bunch fresh dill
1 small bunch fresh mint sprigs

steps.headline: Slice the goat cheese.
steps.description: Get out one 11-ounce (308 g) package of goat cheese. Cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get about 12 thin rounds of cheese. Try to slice the cheese while it's cold. This will make it less crumbly when you cut it.

steps.headline: Put the cheese and oil in the jar.
steps.description: Place the goat cheese rounds on top of the fresh herbs in your jar or bowl. Put the rest of the herbs over the cheese. Get out 2 1/2 to 3 cups (591 to 709 ml) of extra-virgin olive oil out and pour enough of the oil to cover the cheese and herbs. You may not need all 3 cups (709 ml) of the extra virgin olive oil.

steps.headline: Cover and marinate the goat cheese.
steps.description: Put the lid on the mason jar or cover your bowl with plastic wrap. Refrigerate the goat cheese for at least three days. You can marinate the goat cheese up to five days. The longer you marinate the goat cheese, the more flavorful it will become.

steps.headline: Serve the herb marinated goat cheese.
steps.description: When you're ready to serve the goat cheese, remove it from the fridge and gently scoop the cheese out of the jar. Place the cheese on a serving plate. Serve the cheese with crusty baguette or crackers. You can strain the herbed oil through a mesh strainer. Save the flavorful oil for other recipes or to dip flatbread in.

methods.name: Making Sun-Dried Tomato and Garlic Marinated Goat Cheese

steps.headline: Slice the goat cheese.
steps.description: Get out one 11-ounce (308 g) package of goat cheese. Cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get about 12 thin rounds of cheese. Set the cheese aside while you make the sun-dried tomato and garlic marinade. Try to slice the cheese while it's cold. This will make it less crumbly when you cut it.

steps.headline: Roast the garlic.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C). Poke 5 large cloves of unpeeled garlic with a small knife. Put the garlic in a small saucepan and drizzle them with 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Put the garlic in the preheated oven and bake it for 20 minutes. The garlic should become soft and fragrant.

steps.headline: Soak the sun-dried tomatoes.
steps.description: Put 5 sun-dried tomatoes into a heat-proof bowl and pour boiling water over them. Pour enough water to completely cover the tomatoes. Let them soak for about 15 minutes before you drain them. Pat the soaked tomatoes dry using paper towels. The sun-dried tomatoes should plump up and become soft once they've finished soaking.

steps.headline: Assemble the jar of marinated cheese.
steps.description: Get out one 8-ounce (226) jar. Place one sun-dried tomato, one peeled garlic clove, and one sprig each of fresh rosemary and thyme into the jar. Pour half of the oil from the garlic pan into the jar and set one slice of cheese in it. Pour the rest of the oil from the garlic pan over the cheese. The oil will be flavored from the garlic that roasted in the pan.

steps.headline: Layer the rest of the ingredients.
steps.description: Continue to layer the jar with the herbs, oil, and cheese until you've used all of the cheese and four more sprigs each of fresh rosemary and thyme. Get out 1/2 cup (120 ml) of olive oil and pour enough in the jar to fill it to the top. Don't worry if there aren't distinct layers of herbs and cheese.

steps.headline: Marinate the goat cheese.
steps.description: Put a tight lid on the jar, so it's completely sealed. Chill the goat cheese for a few days before you plan on serving it. When you're ready to serve it, open the jar and gently scoop out the cheese. You can marinate the cheese for up to one week. The flavors will intensify the longer it marinates.

methods.name: Making Honey Marinated Goat Cheese With Lavender

steps.headline: Slice the goat cheese.
steps.description: Get out one 4-ounce (112 g) package of goat cheese. If the goat cheese is puck-shaped, slice the puck horizontally, so you get four thin rounds. If the goat cheese is log-shaped, cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get 6 rounds. Try to slice the cheese while it's cold. This will make it easier to cut.

steps.headline: Assemble the goat cheese and drizzle it with honey and lavender.
steps.description: Place the slices of goat cheese on a small serving plate. Drizzle one tablespoon of honey over the cheese. Finely chop 1/2 teaspoon of dried culinary lavender and sprinkle it over the cheese. If you want to use fresh lavender from your garden, ensure that it hasn't been sprayed with chemicals. You may need to use a full teaspoon of the fresh lavender.

steps.headline: Chill and season the goat cheese.
steps.description: Place the plate of honey goat cheese in the refrigerator. Marinate the goat cheese for one hour. This will give the flavors a chance to develop. Sprinkle the goat cheese with a little sea salt according to your taste right before you serve it. Consider serving the honey marinated goat cheese with rosemary crackers or spiced nuts and figs.

tyn: 8-cup (1.81 kg) mason jar with lid or large bowl
text:
Making Herb Marinated Goat Cheese Rinse the fresh herbs and put them in a jar. Rinse small bunches of fresh herbs under cool water or use a mixture of your favorite fresh herbs. Put half of the herbs into an 8-cup (1.81 kg) mason jar. If you don't have that, you can use a large bowl that's at least three inches (7.5 cm) deep. You'll need:
1 small bunch fresh rosemary
1 small bunch fresh thyme
1 small bunch fresh oregano
1 small bunch fresh basil
1 small bunch fresh dill
1 small bunch fresh mint sprigs Slice the goat cheese. Get out one 11-ounce (308 g) package of goat cheese. Cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get about 12 thin rounds of cheese. Try to slice the cheese while it's cold. This will make it less crumbly when you cut it. Put the cheese and oil in the jar. Place the goat cheese rounds on top of the fresh herbs in your jar or bowl. Put the rest of the herbs over the cheese. Get out 2 1/2 to 3 cups (591 to 709 ml) of extra-virgin olive oil out and pour enough of the oil to cover the cheese and herbs. You may not need all 3 cups (709 ml) of the extra virgin olive oil. Cover and marinate the goat cheese. Put the lid on the mason jar or cover your bowl with plastic wrap. Refrigerate the goat cheese for at least three days. You can marinate the goat cheese up to five days. The longer you marinate the goat cheese, the more flavorful it will become. Serve the herb marinated goat cheese. When you're ready to serve the goat cheese, remove it from the fridge and gently scoop the cheese out of the jar. Place the cheese on a serving plate. Serve the cheese with crusty baguette or crackers. You can strain the herbed oil through a mesh strainer. Save the flavorful oil for other recipes or to dip flatbread in. Making Sun-Dried Tomato and Garlic Marinated Goat Cheese Slice the goat cheese. Get out one 11-ounce (308 g) package of goat cheese. Cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get about 12 thin rounds of cheese. Set the cheese aside while you make the sun-dried tomato and garlic marinade. Try to slice the cheese while it's cold. This will make it less crumbly when you cut it. Roast the garlic. Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C). Poke 5 large cloves of unpeeled garlic with a small knife. Put the garlic in a small saucepan and drizzle them with 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Put the garlic in the preheated oven and bake it for 20 minutes. The garlic should become soft and fragrant. Soak the sun-dried tomatoes. Put 5 sun-dried tomatoes into a heat-proof bowl and pour boiling water over them. Pour enough water to completely cover the tomatoes. Let them soak for about 15 minutes before you drain them. Pat the soaked tomatoes dry using paper towels. The sun-dried tomatoes should plump up and become soft once they've finished soaking. Assemble the jar of marinated cheese. Get out one 8-ounce (226) jar. Place one sun-dried tomato, one peeled garlic clove, and one sprig each of fresh rosemary and thyme into the jar. Pour half of the oil from the garlic pan into the jar and set one slice of cheese in it. Pour the rest of the oil from the garlic pan over the cheese. The oil will be flavored from the garlic that roasted in the pan. Layer the rest of the ingredients. Continue to layer the jar with the herbs, oil, and cheese until you've used all of the cheese and four more sprigs each of fresh rosemary and thyme. Get out 1/2 cup (120 ml) of olive oil and pour enough in the jar to fill it to the top. Don't worry if there aren't distinct layers of herbs and cheese. Marinate the goat cheese. Put a tight lid on the jar, so it's completely sealed. Chill the goat cheese for a few days before you plan on serving it. When you're ready to serve it, open the jar and gently scoop out the cheese. You can marinate the cheese for up to one week. The flavors will intensify the longer it marinates. Making Honey Marinated Goat Cheese With Lavender Slice the goat cheese. Get out one 4-ounce (112 g) package of goat cheese. If the goat cheese is puck-shaped, slice the puck horizontally, so you get four thin rounds. If the goat cheese is log-shaped, cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get 6 rounds. Try to slice the cheese while it's cold. This will make it easier to cut. Assemble the goat cheese and drizzle it with honey and lavender. Place the slices of goat cheese on a small serving plate. Drizzle one tablespoon of honey over the cheese. Finely chop 1/2 teaspoon of dried culinary lavender and sprinkle it over the cheese. If you want to use fresh lavender from your garden, ensure that it hasn't been sprayed with chemicals. You may need to use a full teaspoon of the fresh lavender. Chill and season the goat cheese. Place the plate of honey goat cheese in the refrigerator. Marinate the goat cheese for one hour. This will give the flavors a chance to develop. Sprinkle the goat cheese with a little sea salt according to your taste right before you serve it. Consider serving the honey marinated goat cheese with rosemary crackers or spiced nuts and figs. Finished.
sentences: Making Herb Marinated Goat Cheese Rinse the fresh herbs and put them in a jar.
Rinse small bunches of fresh herbs under cool water or use a mixture of your favorite fresh herbs.
Put half of the herbs into an 8-cup (1.81 kg) mason jar.
If you don't have that, you can use a large bowl that's at least three inches (7.5 cm) deep.

You'll need:
1 small bunch fresh rosemary
1 small bunch fresh thyme
1 small bunch fresh oregano
1 small bunch fresh basil
1 small bunch fresh dill
1 small bunch fresh mint sprigs Slice the goat cheese.
Get out one 11-ounce (308 g) package of goat cheese.
Cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get about 12 thin rounds of cheese.
Try to slice the cheese while it's cold.
This will make it less crumbly when you cut it.
Put the cheese and oil in the jar.
Place the goat cheese rounds on top of the fresh herbs in your jar or bowl.
Put the rest of the herbs over the cheese.
Get out 2 1/2 to 3 cups (591 to 709 ml) of extra-virgin olive oil out and pour enough of the oil to cover the cheese and herbs.
You may not need all 3 cups (709 ml) of the extra virgin olive oil.
Cover and marinate the goat cheese.
Put the lid on the mason jar or cover your bowl with plastic wrap.
Refrigerate the goat cheese for at least three days.
You can marinate the goat cheese up to five days.
The longer you marinate the goat cheese, the more flavorful it will become.
Serve the herb marinated goat cheese.
When you're ready to serve the goat cheese, remove it from the fridge and gently scoop the cheese out of the jar.
Place the cheese on a serving plate.
Serve the cheese with crusty baguette or crackers.
You can strain the herbed oil through a mesh strainer.
Save the flavorful oil for other recipes or to dip flatbread in.
Making Sun-Dried Tomato and Garlic Marinated Goat Cheese Slice the goat cheese.
Get out one 11-ounce (308 g) package of goat cheese.
Cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get about 12 thin rounds of cheese.
Set the cheese aside while you make the sun-dried tomato and garlic marinade.
Try to slice the cheese while it's cold.
This will make it less crumbly when you cut it.
Roast the garlic.
Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C).
Poke 5 large cloves of unpeeled garlic with a small knife.
Put the garlic in a small saucepan and drizzle them with 2 tablespoons of the olive oil.
Put the garlic in the preheated oven and bake it for 20 minutes.
The garlic should become soft and fragrant.
Soak the sun-dried tomatoes.
Put 5 sun-dried tomatoes into a heat-proof bowl and pour boiling water over them.
Pour enough water to completely cover the tomatoes.
Let them soak for about 15 minutes before you drain them.
Pat the soaked tomatoes dry using paper towels.
The sun-dried tomatoes should plump up and become soft once they've finished soaking.
Assemble the jar of marinated cheese.
Get out one 8-ounce (226) jar.
Place one sun-dried tomato, one peeled garlic clove, and one sprig each of fresh rosemary and thyme into the jar.
Pour half of the oil from the garlic pan into the jar and set one slice of cheese in it.
Pour the rest of the oil from the garlic pan over the cheese.
The oil will be flavored from the garlic that roasted in the pan.
Layer the rest of the ingredients.
Continue to layer the jar with the herbs, oil, and cheese until you've used all of the cheese and four more sprigs each of fresh rosemary and thyme.
Get out 1/2 cup (120 ml) of olive oil and pour enough in the jar to fill it to the top.
Don't worry if there aren't distinct layers of herbs and cheese.
Marinate the goat cheese.
Put a tight lid on the jar, so it's completely sealed.
Chill the goat cheese for a few days before you plan on serving it.
When you're ready to serve it, open the jar and gently scoop out the cheese.
You can marinate the cheese for up to one week.
The flavors will intensify the longer it marinates.
Making Honey Marinated Goat Cheese With Lavender Slice the goat cheese.
Get out one 4-ounce (112 g) package of goat cheese.
If the goat cheese is puck-shaped, slice the puck horizontally, so you get four thin rounds.
If the goat cheese is log-shaped, cut the goat cheese vertically, so you get 6 rounds.
Try to slice the cheese while it's cold.
This will make it easier to cut.
Assemble the goat cheese and drizzle it with honey and lavender.
Place the slices of goat cheese on a small serving plate.
Drizzle one tablespoon of honey over the cheese.
Finely chop 1/2 teaspoon of dried culinary lavender and sprinkle it over the cheese.
If you want to use fresh lavender from your garden, ensure that it hasn't been sprayed with chemicals.
You may need to use a full teaspoon of the fresh lavender.
Chill and season the goat cheese.
Place the plate of honey goat cheese in the refrigerator.
Marinate the goat cheese for one hour.
This will give the flavors a chance to develop.
Sprinkle the goat cheese with a little sea salt according to your taste right before you serve it.
Consider serving the honey marinated goat cheese with rosemary crackers or spiced nuts and figs.
Finished.
